014package org.jdbi.v3.core.result;
015
016import java.sql.ResultSet;
017import java.sql.SQLException;
018import java.util.function.Supplier;
019
020import org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.StatementContext;
021
022/**
023 * Scan over rows of result sets, mapping and collecting the rows to a result type.
024 * Unlike the Row and ColumnMappers, this interface lets you control the ResultSet
025 * scrolling - the implementation should {@link ResultSet#next()} over rows it wants to consider.
026 *
027 * @param <T> the collected result type
028 * @see org.jdbi.v3.core.result.ResultBearing#scanResultSet(ResultSetScanner)
029 */
030@FunctionalInterface
031public interface ResultSetScanner<T> {
032    /**
033     * Scans the lazily-supplied result set into a result. The ResultSet is not produced
034     * (and typically, the statement the result came from is not executed) until
035     * {@code resultSetSupplier.get()} is called.
036     * <p>
037     * Implementors that call {@code resultSetSupplier.get()} must ensure that the statement context is closed, to
038     * ensure that database resources are freed:
039     * <pre>
040     * try {
041     *     ResultSet resultSet = resultSetSupplier.get()
042     *     // generate and return result from the result set.
043     * }
044     * finally {
045     *     ctx.close();
046     * }
047     * </pre>
048     * <p>
049     * Alternatively, implementors may return some intermediate result object (e.g. {@link ResultIterable}) without
050     * calling {@code resultSetSupplier.get()}, in which case the burden of closing resources falls to whichever object
051     * ultimately does {@code get()} the result set.
052     *
053     * @param resultSetSupplier supplies a ResultSet.
054     * @param ctx               the statement context.
055     * @return the mapped result
056     * @throws SQLException if anything goes wrong
057     */
058    T scanResultSet(Supplier<ResultSet> resultSetSupplier, StatementContext ctx) throws SQLException;
059}
